awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Theoretical and Experimental Investigation of Molecular Mechanism of DNA Synaptic Complex Assembly and Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Genome integrity is a crucial feature defining the successful functioning of cells, their maintenance, and evolution. The genetic processes in the cell require distant communications between the regulatory regions controlled by specific proteins. Mistakes in this interaction process result in termination of the genetic process followed by cell damage, disease development, or cell death. A common feature of these genetic processes is a transient formation of a complex between two DNA segments by specific proteins. However, a molecular model explaining how the proteins recognize specific DNA segments remains uncertain. The combined theoretical and experimental studies under this project are expected to build a novel framework, which will also explain how the search process of distant DNA segments in a long DNA molecule occurs. Several avenues that facilitate the integration of scientific and technological advances in education programs for graduate and undergraduate students are proposed. The concepts of DNA and single molecule biophysics are incorporated into a Biophysical Chemistry course for the UNMC program 'Graduate training in structural biology and biophysics'. These concepts are also included in Biophysical Chemistry and Chemical Kinetics courses that are taught at Rice University as well the participation in the project of undergraduate students from the University of Nebraska-Omaha (UNO) and nation-wide scholars from the UNMC Summer Undergraduate Research program. The PIs will participate in the Young Nebraska Scientists (YNS) program to provide STEM enrichment activities for middle and high school students and activities to attract  the underrepresented minority undergraduate students Summer Research Program at Rice University. A large societal impact from this proposed project will be the training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students at the university level. 

A critical step in numerous fundamental genetic processes is the protein-mediated assembly of a synaptic complex between distant DNA regions. The formation of a synaptic complex is a general phenomenon found in gene regulation (e.g., Lac repressor), site-specific recombination (e.g., Flp, Cre recombinases), and various genome integration systems. Still, little is known regarding the molecular mechanisms that underlie how such proteins search for DNA distant sites during the formation of synaptosomes. If the specific sites needed for the formation of the synaptosome are located on the same DNA molecule the search for the two sites leads to the formation of a loop in the DNA. However, the knowledge on the assembly of synaptosomes is very limited. A proposed comprehensive research plan fills this gap by generating a quantitative model describing the phenomena of the search of specific sites and the synaptosome assembly. This problem is approached by coordinated experimental and theoretical studies to be conducted by labs that specialize in experiments and theory. The central hypothesis behind this project is that sliding and intersegment transfer are the key pathways in the search for two and more sites; the partition between these two pathways specify the dynamics of the site search.  The project objective is to characterize the role of DNA loops and other topological features that define the search process. Successful completion of the innovative work proposed herein will advance knowledge of fundamental processes involved in the DNA synaptosome assembly, which will in turn explain mechanisms involved in the genome rearrangements. The proposed experimental and theoretical approaches will lay a foundation to elucidate mechanisms of such fundamental genetic processes as site-specific recombination, integration, excision, and inversion of specific DNA regions within genomes. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics and Genetic Mechanism clusters of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recognition of specific sites on DNA by regulatory proteins is the key step for all DNA functions. The critical step in numerous fundamental genetic processes is the regulation on distance in which specific regulatory proteins bring the distant regulatory DNA motifs forming synaptic protein-DNA complexes between distant DNA regions. The formation of such synaptic complex is a general phenomenon found in gene regulation, site-specific recombination, and various genome integration systems. Still, little was known regarding the molecular mechanisms that underlie how such proteins search for DNA distant sites during the formation of synaptosomes. Due to a lack of fundamental understanding of the multi-site search in synaptic DNA systems, we proposed a comprehensive plan to generate a quantitative model describing these phenomena. This problem was approached by coordinated experimental and theoretical studies being conducted by labs that specialize in experiments (Dr. Lyubchenko, University of Nebraska Medical Center) and theory (Dr. Kolomeisky, Rice University). Originally our central hypothesis was based on combination of known mechanism of site search processes including sliding and intersegment transfer as the key pathways in the search for two and more sites; the partition between these two pathways specify the dynamics of the site search. However, our studies led to the discovery of the entirely novel site search pathway in which protein bound to two DNA sites threads DNA filament through the sites until specific locations are found. We applied time-lapse high-speed AFM to directly visualize the site search process in real time. With this cutting-edge single molecule approach each site-search process was visualized and characterized. Theoretical modeling was critical in quantitative characterization of the formation and dynamics of looped synaptic complexes. 

We applied our approaches towards understanding the DNA search mechanisms for Apurinic/apyrimidinic Endonuclease 1 (APE1). This multifunctional protein is involved in DNA repair along with transcriptional regulation process. Enrichment of APE1 in gene regulatory regions and participation in transcriptional regulation led to the hypothesis that APE1 can bring together two specific DNA segments on the same DNA molecules, forming a loop. We thoroughly tested this model using single molecule AFM approaches enabling us to visualize DNA loops formed by APE1. Moreover, a quantitative analysis of the AFM data led to the discovery that APE1 has two DNA binding sites enabling a single protein to form synaptic protein-DNA complexes. Our data led us to a model for the interaction of APE1 with DNA and the search the specific sites. This finding leads to the hypothesis that one DNA binding site of APE1 has a strong specificity to G-rich sequences, and the other site is more promiscuous.

The results under this NSF project have been published as joined publications along with publications from both labs separately resulting in 42 publications listed in the PAR sections of final reports submitted by Drs. Kolomeisky and Lyubchenko. 

Several avenues that facilitate the integration of scientific and technological advances in education programs for graduate and undergraduate students are proposed. The concepts of DNA and single molecule biophysics are incorporated into a Biophysical Chemistry course for the UNMC graduate program. These concepts are also included in Biophysical Chemistry and Chemical Kinetics courses that are taught at Rice University as well the participation in the project of undergraduate students from the University of Nebraska-Omaha (UNO) and nation-wide scholars from the UNMC Summer Undergraduate Research program. The PIs will participate in the Young Nebraska Scientists (YNS) program to provide STEM enrichment activities for middle and high school students and activities to attract the underrepresented minority undergraduate students Summer Research Program at both universities. A large societal impact from this proposed project was the training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students at the university level. Chloe Bertelsen, a sophomore from UNO, Department of Chemistry, obtained a permission for working in the lab in the summer of 2021 and continued her research in the fall 2022. The UNMC hosted the 6th Midwest single molecule workshop in August 2-3, 2022, which enabled all participants of the project to present the results of the research along with oral presentations by both PIs. The UNMC graduate student Y. Wang got the first prize for the oral presentation at the workshop. 

A large societal impact from this proposed project was the training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students at the university level. Note the Dr. Hashemi, who worked as a postdoc under this project, has recently got a faculty position at the Auburn University.

Overall, the developed experimental and theoretical approaches laid a foundation to elucidating mechanisms of such fundamental genetic processes as site-specific recombination, integration, excision, and inversion of specific DNA regions within genomes. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
